biogHist.abstract: Wandering Mission was established by the Catholic Archbishop of Perth in 1944, as a day school with a dormitory for Aboriginal girls, run by the Pallottines (Society of the Catholic Apostolates). Boys were admitted from 1951. Children aged 4-15 years were accommodated at Wandering, at the request of parents or government authorities. The head of the government departments responsible for Aboriginal welfare was the guardian of all children until 1963 those who were wards of the State or 'native wards' until 1972. The mission closed in 1979 and some children were transferred to Centrecare Children's Cottages at Beverley, Brookton and Northam.
biogHist.p: Wandering Mission was established by the Catholic Archbishop of Perth, Archbishop Prendiville, in 1944. It was run the by Pallottine fathers and brothers, possibly with involvement from the Schoenstatt Sisters.

Starting as a school for Aboriginal girls from the Reserves in Boddington, Narrogin, Williams, Pingelly and Brookton, Wandering Mission also had boarding facilities for children who couldn't attend on a daily basis.
From 1951, boys were also admitted to Wandering, beginning with boys whose sisters were at the mission.
In 1951, when the Moore River and Carrolup 'native settlements' closed, some of those children were sent to Wandering.

By 1960, children were going out to government primary schools and Boddington Junior High School. Some farm skills training was provided for older youth at the mission. By 1968, some children were housed in cottages rather than dormitories.

The process of closing Wandering mission began around 1978 and discussions about alternative accommodation for the children was discussed by the mission's manager and the newly-appointed head of Catholic welfare in Perth, Father (later, Archbishop) Hickey who was at that time planning to develop 'scatter cottages' to accommodate children family-size homes in towns rather than in dormitories on missions. Thus, Centrecare Children's Cottages were established and, in 1979, children from Wandering were transferred to Centrecare Children's Cottages at Beverley, Brookton and Northam.

chronItem.event: Location - Wandering Mission was located along Mission Road, Wandering

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Department of Aboriginal Affairs [predecessors], Records, Department of Aboriginal Affairs (1886 - 2004)
Department for Community Welfare, State of Western Australia (1972 - 1985)

descriptiveNote.p: The Chief Executive Officer for the Department for Community Welfare, was the guardian of any children at Wandering Mission who were deemed to be 'native wards' or 'wards of the State'.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Western Australian Government Records relating to Child Welfare and Protection (1894 - )

descriptiveNote.p: The Commissioner of Native Affairs was was the guardian of all 'native' children at Wandering Mission.
Wandering Mission was established by the Catholic Archdiocese of Perth.
When the Moore River Native Settlement closed, some children were sent to Wandering Mission.
When Carrolup was discontinued as a 'native settlement', some children were sent to Wandering Mission.
The Commissioner of Native Welfare was was the guardian of all 'native' children at Wandering Mission until 1963 when he could regulate the 'care' of those Aboriginal children.
Children whose parents were participating in rehabilitation programs at Wandering Mission were sometimes sent to Roelands Village.
When Wandering Mission closed, some children were sent to Centrecare Children's Cottages.

archref.repository: West Australian social worker February 1997 p.4-5, State Library of Western Australia
archref.abstract: 'Djooraminda' is by Petrina Butcher. It is a digital copy of an article from the West Australian social worker that is held in the State Library of Western Australia. It gives a brief history of the development of Centrecare Children's Cottages and Djooraminda, to 1997.
